text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC the specter of race hangs over
the democratic presidential primary
campaign today in a way that it hasn't
since the South Carolina primary in
January the question is who's helped and
who's hurt by that and where are they
hurt or help racial voting patterns
fueled Barack Obama's large victory in
Mississippi over Hillary Clinton which
patted his delegate lead even though it
didn't change the structure of the race
Barack Obama got nine and ten
african-american votes Hillary Clinton
got three and four white votes that's a
winning formula for Obama in a state
where half the electorate is black but
of course there are few states were half
the electorate is black so it wouldn't
won't necessarily translate elsewhere
now the other thing keeping race in the
news the comments by Geraldine Ferraro
the former vice presidential nominee to
a California newspaper that Obama would
not be in the position that he's in in
this race unless he were black and the
Obama campaign immediately hit back on
that as an offensive statement demanded
that it be retracted Hillary Clinton
rejected it and she does run a serious
risk of backlash from Obama his campaign
and his supporters if they conclude that
he's diminishing Obama and what Obama
represents but remember that it's Barack
Obama's campaign that has sought through
its strategy in its message to diminish
the salience of race he's trying to
appeal for votes across racial lines he
knows that the vast majority of the
electorate in most of the remaining
contests is made up of whites that's
certainly the case in Pennsylvania which
votes on april twenty second i'm john
harwood chief Washington correspondent
for CNBC
